definition[0]: the past tense and past participle of stick1
definition[1]: impossible or unable to move from a particular position
example[0]: Sara tried to open the window but it was stuck.
example[1]: They got stuck in a traffic jam.
example[2]: I’ve got something stuck in my throat.
example[3]: The boat was stuck in the mud.
definition[2]: unable to escape from a bad or boring situation
example[4]: Mum resented being stuck at home with two young kids.
example[5]: We could be stuck in this place for days.
definition[3]: unable to do any more of something that you are working on because it is too difficult
example[6]: Can you help me with my homework, Dad? I’m stuck.
example[7]: If you get stuck on a difficult word, just ask for help.
definition[4]: fixed or trapped in a particular position or place and unable to move or be moved
example[8]: I can’t open this drawer – it’s stuck.
example[9]: Sorry I’m late – I got stuck in traffic.
definition[5]: stuck and impossible to move – used especially about parts of a machine, or something trapped between two surfaces
example[11]: I put in a 50p coin but it got jammed in the slot.
definition[6]: twisted together and unable to be separated – used especially about things such as hair, wire, or string getting caught around something
example[12]: The chain of her necklace was entangled in her hair.
example[13]: Swimming in the river is dangerous because you might get entangled in the weeds.
definition[7]: stuck and unable to move from or leave a place – used about people, vehicles, and animals
example[14]: Hundreds of motorists were left stranded by the snowstorms.
example[15]: We were stranded at Moscow airport.
example[16]: The jellyfish were stranded on the beach.
definition[8]: stuck in shallow water or on the shore, and unable to move – used about whales, sea creatures, and boats
example[17]: They helped push the beached whale back into the sea.
example[18]: the owner of the beached vessel
